document.docTitle: Parareicheia lencinai Ortuno and Magrini, new species
document.masterDocTitle: A New Species of Parareicheia Jeannel from Eastern Spain (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Scaritinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A New Species of Parareicheia Jeannel from Eastern Spain (Coleoptera: Carabidae: Scaritinae)

heading.emphasis:
Parareicheia lencinai Ortuño and Magrini
, new species

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype : 1 #, Barranc del Curt , Caserío de Bernia , Xaló (Alicante- Spain ),
600 m
; UTM: 30SYH58,
7-II-2004
, V . M. Ortuño and J.L. Lencina leg.

Paratypes : 1 # and 2 $$ þ abdomen and elytra of 1 $, same data as holotype. 1 # and 2 $$ same locality,
9-II-2004
, V . M. Ortuño and J.A. Zaragoza leg.

1 # same locality,
21-V-2004
, V . M. Ortuño leg.

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. Medium sized Reicheiina species with eyes absent. Labrum with seven marginal setae, lateral setae more elongate. Body yellow-brown, antennae, mouth parts and legs a little clearer. Body length (from tip of mandible to elytron-apex) 2.20–2.41 mm (mean of 8 specimens 2.32 mm ).
Description. Head relatively large but narrower than pronotum; maximum width 0.38–0.41 mm (mean of 8 specimens 0.38 mm ). Tempora convex but not very prominent. Deep frontal sulci;

caption.paragraph:
Figs. 9–10.
Parareicheia lencinai Ortuño and Magrini
n.sp. : female genitalia (paratype).

subSubSection.paragraph: 9) gonocoxite IX; 10) spermathecal complex. Scale bar: 0.1 mm .
integument shiny. Eyes absent. Clypeus wide and slightly convex, with notch in apical margin. Frontal surface with an evident keel-like elevation.

Antennae length, 0.76–0.82 mm (mean of 8 specimens 0.79 mm ): 1st antennomere robust; 2nd antennomere long, 0.10–0.12 mm , clearly longer than following antennomeres; 3rd antennomere 0.05–0.06 mm ; 4th antennomere 0.05 mm ; 5th to 10th antennomere subspherical and moniliform; 11th antennomere pyriform longer (0.9– 0.10 mm ) than previous antennomere. Chaetotaxy: two pairs of supraocular setae (anterior and posterior); one seta at both sides of clypeus (next to frontal sulci).

Pronotum subspherical, as long as wide. Disk distinctly convex. Maximum length 0.54–0.59 mm (mean of 8 specimens 0.57 mm ). Maximum width 0.54–0.60 mm (mean of 8 specimens 0.56 mm ). Fore-angles acute; lateral marginal channel not deep, of regular width. Chaetotaxy: one bilateral anterior seta (situated at the end of the first fifth), one bilateral posterior seta situated slightly before the end of fourth.

Elytron with humeral margin weakly defined, fused in suture. Disk convex. Basal margin very slightly oblique. Marginal sulcus deep and wide. Lateral margin smooth with humerus bidentate. Maximum width of elytra at middle, 0.71–0.77 mm (mean of 8 specimens 0.73 mm ). Length from apex to base, 1.18–1.28 mm (mean of 8 specimens 1.23 mm , measured without peduncle), ratio length/width ¼ 3.05–3.34 (mean of 8 specimens 3.16). Eight well-defined striae (1st–7th clearly stippled). Interstriae slightly convex. Apex rounded.

Chaetotaxy: discal setigerous pores with large upright setae, 10–12 situated on the 3rd interstriae, 8–10 on the 5th and 5–6 on the 7th; basal pore present; marginal umbilical series of setigerous tubercles typical for Reicheiina, numerous (around 15 setae) and continuous.
Legs short, robust; foretibia with three spinous teeth, apical tooth specially large.
Aedeagus with overall length 0.41–0.44 mm (mean of 4 specimens 0.42 mm ). Median lobe in lateral, dorsal and ventral view with aspects as in Figures 2, 3, 5 , 7, 8 . Inner sac large, prominent

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 11. Recorded distribution of
Parareicheia species
on the Iberian Peninsula: P. nevesi

subSubSection.paragraph: Female genitalia ( Figs. 9, 10 ). Genital shield ( ¼ external genitalia) with gonopods (gonocoxite IX and gonosubcoxite IX) dimerous; gonosubcoxite IX subtriangular; gonocoxite IX long, unguiform, approximately with 7–8 large setae, two thorn-shaped setae on dorsal surface (situated near external edge); internal structures membranous; short and broad sacciform vagina-bursa; spermatheca filiform ending in spherical ampulla; spermathecal gland present ( Fig. 10 ).
Measurements of thirteen characters used in the analysis of new species are shown in Table 1 .
Etymology. This new species is dedicated to José Luis Lencina in recognition of his effort and collaboration in the entomological expeditions.

Ecological Note. This species has endogeous life in fresh and humid places of the Barranc del Curt, located in the Sierra de Bernia.
P. lencinai
lives buried in the ravine bed, located under large stones. The accompanying entomofauna, including Arachnida and Hexapoda , was very diverse, as follows: Acari Gamasida and Oribatida; Pseudoscopiones; Collembola; Diplura Japigidae; two species of Ponerinae ants [
Ponera coarctata (Latreille 1802)
and
Stenamma cf. debile (Förster 1850)
] and Formicinae ants of the genus
Diplorhoptrum Mayr 1855
and several Coleoptera families. Among the beetles there were a few specimens of other endogeous species: two Anillini of the genus
Microtyphlus Linder 1863
, Leptotyphlinae ( Staphylinidae ), Histeridae of the genus
Sternocoelis Lewis 1884
, Anommatidae and Scydmaenidae .

Morphological Affinities.
P. lencinai
is distinctly different of
P. zoiai
in the following features: a) lack of the ocular vesicle (eye trace); b) longer antennae; c) narrower head; d) pronotum with its basal margin narrower, anterior angle more prominent and epipleura less visible in dorsal view; e) less convex and longer elytron (ratio length/maximum-width 1.63–1.73: mean 1.67; in the single female specimen of
P. zoiai
this ratio is: 1.48); f) elytron with its lateral canal wider and the marginal denticulation limited to two big teeth in the shoulder; however,
P. zoiai
shows the elytron with more extended denticulation.

caption.paragraph:
Table 1. Values of thirteen descriptive characters used in the analysis of
Parareicheia lencinai Ortuño and Magrini
n.sp.

tr.td: to basal sulcus of the peduncle)

subSubSection.paragraph:
With regard to
P. nevesi
the new species shows: a) longer antennae; b) elytral denticulation limited to the shoulder (two teeth), while in
P. nevesi
the denticulation reaches to the middle of the elytron; c) more smooth and longer elytron; d) aedeagus with spatulate longer apex and narrower parameres.

The three species of
Parareicheia
have the lateral canal of the elytron extended up to the extended prolongation of the 5th striae at base although the description of
P. zoiai
states that the canal extends until the 2nd striae.
